name: 5-chloro-2,3-diaminopyridine
Reason: 5-chloro-2,3-diaminopyridine has a melting point influenced by its functional groups relative to the base melting point of benzene, which is around 5°C. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of 5-chloro-2,3-diaminopyridine, we have two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. The chlorine atom introduces a significant withdrawing group, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +50°C. The two nitrogen atoms form a rigid structure, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and increase the melting point by approximately +20°C.
